Psychology_tweet_91_r.News Finding: Learning a lot about sleep from @username. Naps and sleep are very important for young children to enhance emotional memory. Even more reasons for a daytime siesta.
Psychology_tweet_91_r.Paper Finding: Notably, here too with emotional memories, we found a significant association between ΔRecall nap and ΔRecall overnight such that declines in accuracy across the nap were associated with improvements across overnight sleep (B = −0.488, p = 0.029; 95% CI: [−1.294, −0.079]; Fig.
Psychology_tweet_91_r.News Context: Learning a lot about sleep from @username. Naps and sleep are very important for young children to enhance emotional memory. Even more reasons for a daytime siesta.
Psychology_tweet_91_r.Paper Context: In that study, ΔRecall nap predicted ΔRecall overnight , suggesting an interaction of multiple sleep bouts on memory processing. Notably, here too with emotional memories, we found a significant association between ΔRecall nap and ΔRecall overnight such that declines in accuracy across the nap were associated with improvements across overnight sleep (B = −0.488, p = 0.029; 95% CI: [−1.294, −0.079]; Fig. We did not receive caregiver reports for 9 of the children.

Psychology_263_r.News Finding: The result was that all participants rated the four odours more positively when they were presented with positive labels than when presented with negative labels.
Psychology_263_r.Paper Finding: Although labels appear to also influence intensity ratings and reaction times, this seems to be a more complex relationship that could be modulated by additional factors such as odor valence, label fit, and possibly the edibility attributed to an odor or a label.
Psychology_263_r.News Context: When associated with a pleasant label, we enjoy the odour more than when it is presented with a negative label. The result was that all participants rated the four odours more positively when they were presented with positive labels than when presented with negative labels. Specifically, participants described the odours as pleasant and edible (even those associated with non-food items) when associated with positive labels.
Psychology_263_r.Paper Context: In summary, odor labels affect pleasantness ratings and edibility perception. Although labels appear to also influence intensity ratings and reaction times, this seems to be a more complex relationship that could be modulated by additional factors such as odor valence, label fit, and possibly the edibility attributed to an odor or a label. Odors with different valences impact our mood and wellbeing in different ways.
Psychology_263_r.text: ['Finding: The result was that all participants rated the four odours more positively when they were presented with positive labels than when presented with negative labels.']
Psychology_263_r.displayed_text: Finding: The result was that all participants rated the four odours more positively when they were presented with positive labels than when presented with negative labels.

Psychology_510_r.News Finding: Beckley, who is in the department of psychology and neuroscience at Duke, said the adult-onset group had a history of anti-social behavior back to childhood, but reported committing relatively fewer crimes.
Psychology_510_r.Paper Finding: Our results showed that most of the official adult-onset men began their antisocial activities during early childhood.
Psychology_510_r.News Context: Using this unusually rich source of data, the study was able to look at childhood history compared with adult behavior. Beckley, who is in the department of psychology and neuroscience at Duke, said the adult-onset group had a history of anti-social behavior back to childhood, but reported committing relatively fewer crimes. This group reported committing more crimes than folks who had never been convicted, but fewer crimes than people who had been in trouble as juveniles.
Psychology_510_r.Paper Context: Our results, along with past research (see, for example, , indicate that as a whole, apparent adult-onset offenders are responsible for a small minority of total crime. Our results showed that most of the official adult-onset men began their antisocial activities during early childhood. In fact, on average, official adult-onset men were similar to juvenile-onset men on multiple measures of child and adolescent antisocial behavior.
Psychology_510_r.text: ['Finding: Beckley, who is in the department of psychology and neuroscience at Duke, said the adult-onset group had a history of anti-social behavior back to childhood, but reported committing relatively fewer crimes.']
Psychology_510_r.displayed_text: Finding: Beckley, who is in the department of psychology and neuroscience at Duke, said the adult-onset group had a history of anti-social behavior back to childhood, but reported committing relatively fewer crimes.

Psychology_tweet_45_r.News Finding: Immune dysfunction in autism. Pathophysiological pathways.
Psychology_tweet_45_r.Paper Finding: Furthermore, these dysfunctional immune responses are associated with increased impairments in behaviors characteristic of core features of ASD, in particular, deficits in social interactions and communication.
Psychology_tweet_45_r.News Context: Immune dysfunction in autism. Pathophysiological pathways.
Psychology_tweet_45_r.Paper Context: Furthermore, these dysfunctional immune responses are associated with increased impairments in behaviors characteristic of core features of ASD, in particular, deficits in social interactions and communication. This review will discuss the current state of our knowledge of immune dysfunction in ASD, how these findings may impact on underlying neuro-immune mechanisms and implicate potential areas where the manipulation of the immune response could have an impact on behavior and immunity in ASD. There is a concordance rate for ASD of 0-37% reported for dizygotic twins, while concordance rates of 44-91% are reported for monozygotic twins (Bailey et al., 1995; Constantino and Todd, 2000; Kates et al., 2004; Steffenburg et al., 1989) , suggesting that genetic composition may contribute to increased risk of developing ASD.
Psychology_tweet_45_r.text: ['Finding: Immune dysfunction in autism. Pathophysiological pathways. ']
Psychology_tweet_45_r.displayed_text: Finding: Immune dysfunction in autism. Pathophysiological pathways.

Psychology_tweet_220_r.News Finding: Dog's gaze following tuned to human communicative signals:
Psychology_tweet_220_r.Paper Finding: Furthermore, dogs followed the actor's gaze significantly less in the BC compared to the O condition [cumulative accuracy, two-sample t test, t(24) = 22.107, p = 0.045].
Psychology_tweet_220_r.News Context: Dog's gaze following tuned to human communicative signals:
Psychology_tweet_220_r.Paper Context: Importantly, however, the accuracy indexes calculated for the cueing phase did not capture gaze following in BC [mean 6 SEM of cumulative accuracy: 20.06 6 0.14; one-sample t test, t(12) = 20.433; p = 0.67; first look: 0.11 6 0.16; one-sample t test, t(12) = 0.695; p = 0.5]. Furthermore, dogs followed the actor's gaze significantly less in the BC compared to the O condition [cumulative accuracy, two-sample t test, t(24) = 22.107, p = 0.045]. These data suggest that the lack of gaze following, when there are no ostensive signals, cannot be accounted for by the confounding effect of ''artificial'' salient attention getter used in the NO condition, also providing further support for the significant role of ostensive signals in dogs' gaze response.

Psychology_tweet_220_r.displayed_text: Finding: Dog's gaze following tuned to human communicative signals:

Psychology_tweet_144_r.News Finding: New #ReadiLab piece online describing enhanced pleasure from smoking cigs while drinking but not while smoking pot
Psychology_tweet_144_r.Paper Finding: In contrast, there was on average no change in perceived pleasure from smoking cigarettes when using marijuana (5.3 ± 2.7, t (199) ¼ 1.7, p ¼ .09).
Psychology_tweet_144_r.News Context: New #ReadiLab piece online describing enhanced pleasure from smoking cigs while drinking but not while smoking pot
Psychology_tweet_144_r.Paper Context: Individuals reported an increase in perceived pleasure from smoking cigarettes when drinking alcohol (7.0 ± 2.2 versus null hypothesis 5 ¼ "no increase or decrease in pleasure"; t (199) ¼13.0, p < .001). In contrast, there was on average no change in perceived pleasure from smoking cigarettes when using marijuana (5.3 ± 2.7, t (199) ¼ 1.7, p ¼ .09). Perceived pleasure from smoking cigarettes did not differ by frequency of binge drinking (F (3,200) ¼ 0.84, p ¼ .47): nonbinge (7.1 ± 2.1), 1-3 binge days (6.8 ± 2.3), 4-8 binge days (7.0 ± 2.1), 9 þ binge days (7.6 ± 2.2).
Psychology_tweet_144_r.text: ['Finding: New #ReadiLab piece online describing enhanced pleasure from smoking cigs while drinking but not while smoking pot ']
Psychology_tweet_144_r.displayed_text: Finding: New #ReadiLab piece online describing enhanced pleasure from smoking cigs while drinking but not while smoking pot
